channel.title: Comments on: Filledcurves with different transparency

item.title: By: hadr1an
item.dc:creator: hadr1an
item.description:
Is there a way to use this with data from the two columns of a file like the command: " plot 'output.dat' u 1:2 w l " ?
I get an error at the fs argument...
item.content:encoded:
Is there a way to use this with data from the two columns of a file like the command: ” plot ‘output.dat’ u 1:2 w l ” ?

I get an error at the fs argument…

item.title: By: stemokrates
item.dc:creator: stemokrates
item.description: Ah well, thats the problem with bookmarks, I guess. On the other hand: It does show that I do have your blog on my bookmark list for quite some time now.
item.content:encoded:
Ah well,
thats the problem with bookmarks, I guess.
On the other hand: It does show that I do have your blog on my bookmark list for quite some time now.

item.title: By: hagen
item.dc:creator: hagen
item.description: Thanks for your feedback, and don't worry I will continue with the blog. By the way, the <a href="./../../matplotlib-colormaps/">last/index.html entry</a> is only ten days old ;)
item.content:encoded:
Thanks for your feedback, and don’t worry I will continue with the blog.
By the way, the last entry is only ten days old ;)

item.title: By: stemokrates
item.dc:creator: stemokrates
item.description:
This is just a quick "Thank you" for providing this website. I regularly take a look at your blog when having some kind of a problem with gnuplot.
Thanks to your "code to reproduce this figure" examples, I almost always find a hint to help myself afterwards.
With gnuplot 5.0 out and the last entry in your blog being quite some time ago, I can only hope that you plan to continue this blog in the future.
item.content:encoded:
This is just a quick “Thank you” for providing this website.
I regularly take a look at your blog when having some kind of a problem with gnuplot.

Thanks to your “code to reproduce this figure” examples, I almost always find a hint to help myself afterwards.

With gnuplot 5.0 out and the last entry in your blog being quite some time ago, I can only hope that you plan to continue this blog in the future.

item.title: By: Tulsi Ram Sahu
item.dc:creator: Tulsi Ram Sahu
item.description: Do any one can suggest me that how to make filled curves transparent in eps format
item.content:encoded: Do any one can suggest me that how to make filled curves transparent in eps format

item.title: By: Olivier MOF
item.dc:creator: Olivier MOF
item.description: I want to draw the area between f(x), g(x) et k(x) f(x)=1125*x g(x)=350*x k(x)=-37.5*x+4650 plot [0:40][0:6000]f(x), g(x), k(x)
item.content:encoded:
I want to draw the area between f(x), g(x) et k(x)
f(x)=1125*x
g(x)=350*x
k(x)=-37.5*x+4650
plot [0:40][0:6000]f(x), g(x), k(x)

item.title: By: hagen
item.dc:creator: hagen
item.description: You can use fill style with <code>epslatex</code>, but transparency will not work. There are <a href="http://sourceforge.net/p/gnuplot/bugs/1168/#8762" rel="nofollow">some claims</a> that transparency is working with postscript, but I never managed to get it to work. If you really need transparency you could try the <code>pdfcairo</code> output which gives you an identical results to the <code>pngcairo</code> terminal used in this post.
item.content:encoded: You can use fill style with epslatex, but transparency will not work. There are some claims that transparency is working with postscript, but I never managed to get it to work. If you really need transparency you could try the pdfcairo output which gives you an identical results to the pngcairo terminal used in this post.

item.title: By: Hirschler Thibaut

item.description: How can I use fill style with epslatex terminal ? Which packages are needed ? Thank you.
item.content:encoded: How can I use fill style with epslatex terminal ? Which packages are needed ? Thank you.
